[[File:Đuro Arnold 1898 Povjest književnosti hrvatske i srpske.png|thumb|Đuro Arnold]] '''Đuro Arnold''' (24 March 1853 – 22 February 1941) was a [[Croatia]]n writer and [[philosopher]].<ref name="PROLEKSIS">{{citation |contribution-url=http://proleksis.lzmk.hr/8207/ |contribution=Arnold, Đuro |title=[[Proleksis Encyclopedia]] |date=September 2013 |publisher=[[Leksikografski zavod Miroslav Krleža]] |language=Croatian}}</ref>
==Early life and study== Arnold was born as the 19th of 24 children of Ivan, a [[tax gatherer]], and Sofija, née [[Vukanić]]. His ancestors arrived from [[Switzerland]] during the [[French Revolution]].<ref name="HBL">{{citation |contribution-url=http://hbl.lzmk.hr/clanak.aspx?id=856 |contribution=ARNOLD, Đuro |last=Flego |first=Višnja |author-link=Višnja Flego |last2=Kaminski |first2=Martin |author2-link=Martin Kaminski |title=[[Croatian Biographical Lexicon]] |year=1983 |volume=1 |publisher=[[Leksikografski zavod Miroslav Krleža]] |language=Croatian}}</ref> He was born in [[Ivanec]] and spent his early childhood in [[Krapina]]. He attended [[primary school]] in [[Zagreb]], and high school in [[Varaždin]] and Zagreb, where he graduated in 1873.
In 1874 he enrolled at the [[Faculty of Philosophy in Zagreb]] majoring in [[philosophy]], with a minor in [[history]] and [[geography]]. During the [[Bosnian crisis]] he was recruited, and it was only in 1879 that he was hired as a professor in a Zagreb [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]]. In 1880 he was promoted as the first PhD in philosophy at the [[University of Zagreb]], with a thesis ''Ethics and history'' (''Etika i povijest''), which was published in 1879.<ref name="HBL"/> He continued his studies at the universities of [[University of Göttingen|Göttingen]] (1880), Berlin and Paris (1881/1882).
== Work == Since 1889 he served as the Director of the Royal Teacher's School. In 1894 he was appointed as a professor extraordinarius, and since 1896 as the full professor of theoretical and practical philosophy and pedagogy at the [[Faculty of Philosophy in Zagreb]]. He retired in 1923. He was the dean of the Faculty of Arts in the periods of 1898-1899, and 1912-1913, and also the rector of the [[University of Zagreb]] in the period 1899-1900.
He was appointed as a corresponding member of the [[Yugoslav Academy of Sciences and Arts]] in 1891, and as a full member in 1899. He served as the president of [[Matica hrvatska]] in 1902–1909. In 1892 he became an honorary member of the Croatian Pedagogic-Literary Society, in 1924 a member of the Society of the Brothers of the Croatian Dragon, and an [[honorary citizen]] of [[Krapina]].<ref name="HBL"/>
==Writer== As a writer, his work is a continuation of Croatia's romantic poetry in the tradition of [[August Šenoa]] and [[Franjo Marković]].<ref name="PROLEKSIS"/> His first appearance as a writer was the song ''Pri povratku'' ("On the way back", ''Vienac'', 1873, 49). He mostly published patriotic songs, romances and [[ballad]]s with themes from [[Croatian history]] and [[folklore]] (''Krapinske elegije'', ''Damjan Juda, knez dubrovački'', ''Kata Lovićeva'' etc.), as well as reflexive lyricism in publications such as [[Vienac]] (1873-1886, 1888-1891, 1893-1902 ), [[Hrvatska lipa]] (1875), [[Hrvatski dom]] (1876), [[Obzor]] (1898, 1900, 1901, 1904), [[Prosvjeta]] (1904–1913), [[Hrvatsko kolo]] (1905, 1906, 1908, 1930), [[Katolički list]] (1906, 1915, 1916), [[Hrvatska smotra]] (1907–1910, 1933), [[Hrvatsko pravo]] (1908, 1924), [[Koledar hrvatskoga katoličkoga narodnoga đaštva]] (1909, 1910), [[Serafinski perivoj]] (1909–1913), [[Književni prilog]] (1911, 1912, 1913–1915), [[Hrvatska (publication)|Hrvatska]] (1912, 1914, 1915), [[Hrvatska prosvjeta]] (1914–1918), [[Naša misao]] (1914, 1915 ), [[Jeka od Osijeka]] (1918, 1919), [[Vijenac]] (1923, 1925, 1927), [[Hrvatsko pravo]] (1924, 1925), [[Omladina]] (1924, 1925), [[Hranilovićeva spomenica]] (1925), [[Selo i grad]] (1928/1929, 1930, 1931), [[Hrvatski list]] (1939), [[Novo doba]] (1940) and others. He wrote a single short story ''Samo četvrt sata'' (Vienac, 1880, 15–18).<ref name="HBL"/>
He signed his works in codes and pseudonyms: ''A.'', ''G. A.'', ''Gj. A.'', ''Gj. A-d'', ''Gj. Ar.'', ''O. D.'', ''R. R.'', ''Ivančanin'', ''Georg Arnold''.<ref name="HBL"/> He published several books of poems, and the poem ''Domovina'' has gained him popularity.<ref name="HBL"/> His works were published in many anthologies, calendars and almanacs. The selection of his poetry was translated to [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Esperanto]], [[German language|German]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]] and [[Italian language|Italian]]. He expressed his views on literature in talks at the Matica hrvatska conferences: ''Umjetnost prema znanosti'', ''Može li umjetnost zamijeniti vjeru'', ''Jedinstvena hrvatska narodna kultura'' (Glas Matice hrvatske, 1906, 1908, 1909).<ref name="HBL"/>
==Philosopher== As a philosopher, he was influenced by [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]], [[Johann Friedrich Herbart]] and [[Hermann Lotze]], representing the "spiritualist positivism" movement and the view that the knowledge of the world can be reached only by the combined efforts of [[science]], [[art]] and [[religion]].<ref name="PROLEKSIS"/> He wrote on the fundamental questions of philosophy, which he defined as the science of "final causes and purposes of being".<ref>''Logika'', p. 40</ref>
In the treatise ''Zadnja bića'' ("Last beings", Rad JAZU, 1888, 93 ) he conceived a world composed from the variety of simple, immutable soullike "last beings" that are connected by the feeling of touch and hierarchically arranged according to different levels of awareness, with absolute consciousness, the [[God]], occupying the peak of the hierarchy.<ref name="HBL"/> According to Arnold, faith represents the supreme stronghold of a man and the basic principle of harmony of his spiritual functions.<ref name="HE">{{citation |contribution-url=http://www.enciklopedija.hr/Natuknica.aspx?ID=3953 |contribution=Arnold, Đuro (Gjuro) |title=[[Croatian Encyclopedia]] |year=1999–2009 |publisher=[[Leksikografski zavod Miroslav Krleža]] |language=Croatian}}</ref>
According to some opinions, in his later works such as ''O psihologiji bez duše'' and ''Monizam i kršćanstvo'' (Rad JAZU, 1909, 176 and 178) Arnold has abandoned his earlier philosophical views. Others such as [[Pavao Vuk-Pavlović]], [[Stjepan Matičević]] and [[Blaženka Despot]] however maintain that Arnold's philosophical view was uniform and consistent - spiritualist pluralism which doesn't completely exclude spiritualist [[monism]].<ref name="HBL"/>
Arnold is one of the founders of the Croatian philosophical terminology,<ref name="PROLEKSIS"/> having authored two influential high school textbooks (''Logika'' and ''Psihologija'') that were standard textbooks for more than thirty years.<ref name="HBL"/>
At Arnold's proposal, in 1896 the Pedagogical Seminar for theoretical and practical training of future secondary school teachers was founded at the Faculty of Philosophy in Zagreb. As a teacher, organizer of educational system, the first Professor of Pedagogy at the Faculty of Philosophy and the first head of the Pedagogical Seminar, has influenced many generations of teachers.<ref name="HBL"/>
Arnold died in Zagreb.
==Works== In literature: * ''Izabrane pjesme'', 1899, Zagreb * ''Čeznuća i maštanja i pjesme'', 1900–1907, Zagreb * ''S visina i dubina'', 1918, Zagreb * ''Izabrane pjesme'', 1923, Zagreb * ''Na pragu vječnosti'', 1935, Zagreb
In philosophy: * ''Etika i poviest'', 1879, Zagreb * ''Logika za srednja učilišta'', 1888<sup>1</sup>, 1923<sup>5</sup>, Zagreb * ''Psihologija za srednja učilišta'', 1893<sup>1</sup>, 1923<sup>7</sup>, Zagreb
